msIdentifier.repository: National Archives and Records Administration, Seattle Branch, Washington
msIdentifier.collection: RG 21: US District Court, Western Division of Washington, Seatle

div1.p: ROBERT TATE 821 Campbell Ave. called as a witness, being first sworn, testified as follows:
50 Q. What is your occupation? A Porter and waiter.
51 Q. Do you know Lewis Johnston? A Yes sir
52 Q. How long have you known him? A. A little over a year
53 Q. Do you remember the 4th of June? A. I really don't know the date, but I remember Friday, Saturday morning. I paid no attention to the date.
54 Q. How many Saturdays ago? A. Pardon me, just a minute. I paid no attention to the date.
55 Q. But how many weeks ago? Would you know how many Saturdays have intervened since then? A. The Saturday before last.
56 Q. That would be the 5th. Did you see Johnston on that date A. He came to the house where I live between four and five in the morning
57 Q. Where do you live? A. 821 Campbell Avenue
58 Q. And alone? A. Yes sir I room a lone but there are other people in the house.

59 Q. Now I want you to tell us in your own words, please, with out any prompting what conversation you had with Johnston in connection with this charge? A. He came to the house between 4 and 5 in the morning - I didn't notice the time so much either - but he came there really early in the morning and knocked at the back door, and the lady of the house opened the door and he asked her for "Bob"

60 Q. You are "Bob", eh? A. Yes. He said "I want to see him on some very important business" So she opened the door and he came in, and he was in the kitchen when I came down, and she called to me that Mr Johnston wanted to see me on some very important business; and I went out there and he had a bottle of Gin and several packages of cigarettes; and he said he came to give me the time of my life, that he was going to the States; and I sat down and had a drink; and he said he had come into some money
